name: Continue
tagline: Open‑source IDE extensions and CLI to build custom AI coding agents.
summary:
Continue is an open‑source AI coding assistant that ships IDE extensions for VS Code and JetBrains plus an open CLI for terminal‑first and CI/CD scenarios. Its core idea is control: you choose the models (local or hosted), decide what context to feed them, and define custom tools and automations through a hub of community‑contributed integrations. Documentation shows how to connect to model providers, enable terminal‑native TUI mode for interactive development, and run headless in pipelines for batch changes. Because Continue is open‑source, organizations can inspect and extend it to suit internal policies and infrastructure.

Teams use Continue to avoid vendor lock‑in while still getting AI‑assisted editing, chat, and multi‑file operations. The CLI supports scripted refactors, pre‑commit hooks, and CI jobs that run AI‑assisted codemods; IDE extensions bring chat and completions to developer workstations. A Continue Hub catalogs templates and tools so teams can standardize on opinionated agents (e.g., a refactoring agent that enforces style rules). Tutorials and the official YouTube channel demonstrate setup, custom tools, and examples of connecting to popular LLMs and vector databases. 

Continue is best for engineers who want an extensible, inspectable assistant that integrates with existing editors and tooling. Migration is straightforward: install the IDE extension or CLI, configure model credentials, and adopt templates across teams. Enterprises can fork the project and manage internal plugins or tools to align with governance requirements.
key_differentiators: Open source across IDE, CLI, and CI
limitations: Feature set depends on connected models/tools
setup_time: Minutes to install; time to configure models/tools varies
migration_paths: Install extension/CLI; configure model providers; roll out templates across teams
alternatives_notes: Alternatives: Aider (CLI), VS Code + Copilot, other open assistants
